articles.headline: How Philippe Dauman Lost the Battle for Viacom
articles.snippet: The daughter of Sumner Redstone achieved almost total victory in her fight to control the vast media empire, and Mr. Dauman was the biggest casualty.
articles.abstract: The daughter of Sumner Redstone achieved almost total victory in her fight to control the vast media empire, and Mr. Dauman was the biggest casualty.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a few weeks ago, things seemed to be breaking Philippe A. Dauman’s way in his legal bid to maintain his grip on Viacom — which owns, among other things MTV, Comedy Central and Paramount Pictures — by having its majority owner and chairman, the 93-year-old media mogul Sumner Redstone, declared mentally incompetent.

articles.headline: Democrats’ Weak Bench Undermines Hope of Taking Back Senate
articles.snippet: Various flaws mar many of the party’s candidates, despite a year when the Republicans have chosen a contentious presidential candidate.
articles.abstract: Various flaws mar many of the party’s candidates, despite a year when the Republicans have chosen a contentious presidential candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats, aware of the dead weight that Donald J. Trump has placed on their vulnerable Republican colleagues, can taste a reclaimed majority.

articles.headline: Donald Trump, Wavering on Immigration, Finds Anger in All Corners
articles.snippet: After Mr. Trump indicated he might retreat from his vow to deport all immigrants in the United States illegally, disgust poured in from all sides, if for different reasons.
articles.abstract: After Mr. Trump indicated he might retreat from his vow to deport all immigrants in the United States illegally, disgust poured in from all sides, if for different reasons.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 15 months, even as Donald J. Trump vacillated on many other issues, he stuck to a simple, hard-line position on immigration: If elected president, he would form a “deportation force,” round up people who are in the United States illegally and send them back where they came from.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: California Aims Retirement Plan at Those Whose Jobs Offer None
articles.snippet: The plan would cover an estimated six million people and could make the state the first to require companies to take part in such a system.
articles.abstract: The plan would cover an estimated six million people and could make the state the first to require companies to take part in such a system.
articles.lead_paragraph: California is preparing to create a mandatory state-run retirement plan for an estimated six million workers at companies that do not now offer any retirement benefits.

articles.headline: Frank Ocean’s ‘Blonde’ Amplifies Discord in the Music Business
articles.snippet: The album’s release, through an exclusive deal with Apple, surfaced long-simmering tensions between record labels, streaming services and artists.
articles.abstract: The album’s release, through an exclusive deal with Apple, surfaced long-simmering tensions between record labels, streaming services and artists.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shoo-in for No. 1 on Billboard’s next album chart is Frank Ocean’s “Blonde,” which has charmed critics and enthralled fans who had waited four years since his last record.

articles.headline: VW to Pay $1.2 Billion to U.S. Dealers Hurt by Diesel Scandal
articles.snippet: The settlement, still subject to a federal judge’s approval, is meant to address lost sales and the declining value of Volkswagen dealerships.
articles.abstract: The settlement, still subject to a federal judge’s approval, is meant to address lost sales and the declining value of Volkswagen dealerships.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not that long ago, Volkswagen dealerships were among the hottest properties in the retail auto business.

articles.headline: Painted as EpiPen Villain, Mylan’s Chief Says She’s No Such Thing
articles.snippet: Heather Bresch, defending her company against criticism for sharply increasing the price of the life-saving device, is unapologetic. “I am running a business,” she says.
articles.abstract: Heather Bresch, defending her company against criticism for sharply increasing the price of the life-saving device, is unapologetic. “I am running a business,” she says.
articles.lead_paragraph: America has a new pharmaceutical villain. Her name is Heather Bresch.

articles.headline: Syria’s Paradox: Why the War Only Ever Seems to Get Worse
articles.snippet: Experts on civil wars say there are several reasons Syria is “a really, really tough case” that defies historical parallels.
articles.abstract: Experts on civil wars say there are several reasons Syria is “a really, really tough case” that defies historical parallels.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is a basic fact about Syria’s civil war that never seems to change: It frustrates any attempt at resolution.

articles.headline: A Cheaper Airbag, and Takata’s Road to a Deadly Crisis
articles.snippet: Automakers embraced Takata’s cheaper technology almost 20 years ago despite signs that it was unsafe. The airbags are now at the center of the auto industry’s biggest recall.
articles.abstract: Automakers embraced Takata’s cheaper technology almost 20 years ago despite signs that it was unsafe. The airbags are now at the center of the auto industry’s biggest recall.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the late 1990s, General Motors got an unexpected and enticing offer. A little-known Japanese supplier, Takata, had designed a much cheaper automotive airbag.

articles.headline: Court Overturns ‘Burkini’ Ban in French Town
articles.snippet: The court ruled that the prohibition in Villeneuve-Loubet violated civil liberties, in a warning that could affect other communities that have banned the swimwear.
articles.abstract: The court ruled that the prohibition in Villeneuve-Loubet violated civil liberties, in a warning that could affect other communities that have banned the swimwear.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s highest administrative court on Friday overturned a town’s ban on burkinis, the full-body swimwear used by some Muslim women, setting a precedent that challenges similar bans in at least 30 other municipalities, most of them on the French Riviera.
articles.byline: By Aurelien Breeden and Lilia Blaise

articles.headline: Yellen Sees Stronger Case for Interest Rate Increase
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve chief, in a speech, pointed to gains in the job market and economic outlook. But the Fed is not expected to act before December.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve chief, in a speech, pointed to gains in the job market and economic outlook. But the Fed is not expected to act before December.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK, Wyo. — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Friday that she saw a stronger case for raising the Fed’s benchmark interest rate, suggesting the central bank was likely to act in the coming months.

articles.headline: Cloud Computing Brings Sprawling Centers, but Few Jobs, to Small Towns
articles.snippet: As big companies race to build oversize data networks, communities are finding that the giant buildings can operate with only about 30 people.
articles.abstract: As big companies race to build oversize data networks, communities are finding that the giant buildings can operate with only about 30 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOYDTON, Va. — A giant Microsoft facility just outside this very small town hides behind a quarter-mile berm and a guard house, across the highway from the rubble of a demolished prison.

articles.headline: 7 Essential Money Questions Sure to Start a Conversation
articles.snippet: Questions that focus on family, feelings and the future we plan for ourselves.
articles.abstract: Questions that focus on family, feelings and the future we plan for ourselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s the season of the long hike, the slow beach stroll, the idle time when you can finally just talk and think for at least a little while. Even if you don’t get to go on vacation over these next two weeks, many workplaces will be quieter than usual, allowing, perhaps, for an early escape and a longer evening meal.

articles.headline: How Bankrupt Is Horsehead Holding? Its Investors Want to Know
articles.snippet: Shareholders of a metals products company say it has lowballed its asset values in bankruptcy to give leading creditors control at a bargain price.
articles.abstract: Shareholders of a metals products company say it has lowballed its asset values in bankruptcy to give leading creditors control at a bargain price.
articles.lead_paragraph: In large and complex corporate bankruptcies, shareholders are usually kicked to the curb, left with nothing of any value to show for their investments. Normally, that’s the way it should be: Bankruptcies, after all, involve companies whose assets are worth far less than their obligations.
